title: Repetition, Parallelism and Creativity: An Inquiry into the Construction of Meaning in Ancient Mesopotamian Literature and Erudition
descriptions: The "Repetition, Parallelism and Creativity: An Inquiry into the Construction of Meaning in Ancient Mesopotamian Literature and Erudition" project, identified by the acronym REPAC, delves into the intricate world of Ancient Mesopotamian civilization, specifically focusing on the textual form and function within various genres such as literary, magical, and mantic works inscribed on clay tablets in the Cuneiform script using the Akkadian language during the first millennium BCE. The project aims to explore the textual features of exact repetition, variant repetition, parallelism, refrain, and ring composition, and their roles in enhancing poetic creativity, rhetorical effectiveness, and argumentation inventiveness. By delving into the scribes' worldview and their beliefs in interconnections, causal effectiveness, and similarity, the project seeks to bridge the gap in understanding the Mesopotamian literary and scholarly methods, particularly in terms of aesthetic ornamentation, analogical reasoning, argument construction, and magical action. Ultimately, the expected outcome of this project is an improved understanding of the creative efforts of Ancient Mesopotamian scholars and scribes in constructing meaning through repetitive and parallel textual structures. This research will shed light on the worldview and analogical reasoning prevalent in Mesopotamian literature, enriching our knowledge of this ancient civilization's cultural and intellectual achievements.

The proposed project, titled "Repetition, Parallelism and Creativity: An Inquiry into the Construction of Meaning in Ancient Mesopotamian Literature and Erudition" (REPAC), aims to explore the intricate relationship between textual form and function in Ancient Mesopotamian literary and scholarly compositions. Focusing on genres such as literary, magical, and mantic texts inscribed on clay tablets in Cuneiform script during the first millennium BCE, the project will investigate the use of exact repetition, variant repetition, parallelism, refrain, and ring composition as structuring devices.

By analyzing the textual features and functions within these ancient writings, the project seeks to enhance our understanding of Mesopotamian creative effort and the worldview of its scribes. The research will address a knowledge gap in the field by delving into the aesthetic ornamentation, analogical reasoning, argument construction, and magical action embedded in these texts. Ultimately, the expected outcome of the project is an improved understanding of Ancient Mesopotamian literary and scholarly methods, shedding light on the creative processes and cultural beliefs of this civilization. Through this inquiry, the project aims to contribute valuable insights to the study of ancient literature and erudition.

The proposed project, titled "Repetition, Parallelism and Creativity: An Inquiry into the Construction of Meaning in Ancient Mesopotamian Literature and Erudition," seeks to deepen our understanding of Ancient Mesopotamian creative efforts. Focusing on the textual features of exact repetition, variant repetition, and parallelism found in literary, magical, and mantic genres on clay tablets written in Cuneiform script in Akkadian language during the first millennium BCE, the project aims to explore the relationship between textual form and function. By analyzing the poetic creativity, rhetorical effectiveness, and argumentation inventiveness in these texts, the project intends to shed light on the aesthetic ornamentation, analogical reasoning, argument construction, and magical action employed by Mesopotamian scribes. Additionally, the project will investigate the scribes' worldview, particularly their beliefs in interconnection, causal effectiveness, and similarity. Through this research, the project aims to address the knowledge gap in understanding the worldview and analogy in Mesopotamian literary and scholarly methods. The expected outcome of this project is an improved understanding of the creative efforts of Ancient Mesopotamian scribes, enriching our knowledge of this ancient civilization's literary and scholarly practices.
